history.content:
Not an answer to your question, but you could probably just use a drum trigger and then find all of the information you want from the data it gives you.

response: yeah, but that takes away the fun from doing it yourself :( many drum triggers also have preconfigured software for eliminating that sort of crosstalk and detecting if things are actual hits, and are less hackable overall? thanks for the suggestion though :)
Not an answer to your question, but you could probably just use a drum trigger and then find all of the information you want from the data it gives you.

Hi fellow CS/EECS/etc people,

Tryin to do a hobby electronics project for fun over break involving some piezo elements/knock sensors for detecting and transmitting drum hits so they can be translated into musical notation. The 'challenges' I guess are configuring and processing the piezo outputs such that you can distinguish whether you're hitting with the left/right stick, distinguish between two levels of dynamics (soft/hard), and make the setup somewhat durable so that a few taps from a drumstick won't break it.

Anybody willing to help? :P I'm not great with electronics so any help would be appreciated! LMK and i'll send contact info your way.
history.subject: HELP WANTED: hobby electronics project for detecting drum taps - anyone good with this stuff?
